comments.commentBody: Cleaver point save the recognized fact that Marx is hard to find in western thought as is the other ‘wise man’ Lenin. Marx is also a little difficult to find in content in China today but Lenin is doing well in the structure of the CCP. Education Minister Chen Baosheng is the little man trying hard to please the boss, but having described Christmas, a forbidden western Holiday,  to four separate class rooms in three different cities, I think its safe to say the teachers may not be listening.

You have the wrong adversary perhaps, the Left however defined has little input into what you are worrying about that sounds like ‘Globalization’. The driving force there in Neo-Liberalism and its champions are Corporate Interest and the politicians who conform to those interest – a very long way from old fashioned Liberalism. IBO schooling in China is probably doing the children some good in making integration into Western Universities more graceful. But would not go on to think that changes their perception of being Chinese, that is buried much deeper.
A suggestion I came across years ago for puzzlers who find Mondays and Tuesdays less than challenging: use only the horizontal clues; no cheating. It's kind of fun.

I remember my high school years in state college high in penn. The american students and chinese students quickly developed a poisonous relationship: the chinese students told me americans really hate china and is trying to dismantle their country by assisting dissidents and dalai lama. And yet the west still denies subverting china, how ironic.

Bureaucracies generally need two pools of employees. One pool consists of analysts and designers who identify and clarify challenges, create response strategies and systems to address those, and relate behavior to performance. The second pool are the operators whose attention to day-to-day matters help to assure agencies function effectively yet have the stand-by capabilities to ramp up when needed. Most of the Center for Disease Control operations are routine although highly technical but it needs the capability to address unknown diseases during an epidemic. What keeps these capacities efficient are the middle managers constantly confronting the balance between the routine and the exceptional, the familiar and the new. Donald Trump has some familiarity with the operational needs of the real estate and entertainment industries but how well does he understand the relationship between direct service clinical personnel in the V.A. and the management of outreach services vs. records control? How will a hiring freeze affect departmental IT units compared to public information services? What Trump seems to want is a reduction in service effectiveness so there are fewer audits of high net worth individuals or inspectors to make sure fecal matter is not included in ground meat at your supermarket. As the husband of a federal employee in law enforcement I assume he wants my wife tracking the smuggling and finance operations of international drug cartels. But then again perhaps not.

Perhaps Trump does not want your wife tracking international drug cartels because he knows the war on drugs and its associated beauracracies have been utter failures, producing no discernable benefit and costing the USA-- yes, trillions!
When something sounds really stupid, like exposing the whole body to temperatures of -200 degrees; it sounds really stupid, because it is.

If the Democratic program is far left, then all other prosperous countries are far left and far-left is normal for prosperous countries. Actually it is far-left only to modern Republicans who have become far right. A conservative approach to the New Deal would be to gradually trim its excesses; getting rid of it quickly in large chunks is radical and based on a faith that market forces will quickly emerge to replace government planning and regulation.

The reason for the rise in entitlements is that people are living longer because of sometimes-expensive medical care that did not exist in the past. The market solution to this rise is exemplified in the drop in lifespan of whites who did not go to college.

UnFAMILIAR with LORAIN, and I've become so tethered to my IPhone that "Neighborhood buzz?" meaning a LOCAL CALL had me nonplussed for a moment. (This reminds me of a great joke involving a travel agent that I can't repeat here, but "travel agent" is another 2-letter phrase that is fading into obscurity - so if you show up while I'm tending bar I'll have to tell you that joke immediately!) Anyhow, it took me a couple of trips around the grid to fill this one. Probably 4, actually. So - extremely gettable but a satisfying exercise.

This comment seems so out of touch with the expectations placed upon today's doctoral students. Forty years ago, faculty were still being hired with a well-placed phone call from their graduate advisors, and completion of the dissertation was the sole expectation. Today (in a field like literature) roughly one-quarter of recently minted Ph.D.s will actually land full-time, tenure track positons, and will have published half a dozen articles and maybe a book or two before being hired. The rest will either find work outside of academics, or barely sustain themselves in a life of piecing together adjunct teaching jobs. You're correct that many universities who never place their students in jobs do exploit them for their cheap labor. But the sad fact is that in most fields, less than a dozen programs produce 90% of the hires, and those programs are every bit as rigorous than leading programs forty years ago, with the added element of dramatically higher levels of competition. Sadly, a consequence of this hyper-competition is the felt need to give catchy titles to conference papers, but to imagine this is a sign of decreased rigor suggests you may be fairly removed from what goes on in higher education today.

Mongolia is a landlocked country stuck between Russia and China, and
was a part of China until WWII, under an accord between USSR and Nationalist government, a continuation of over 100 years of history of
China losing territory as well as sovereignty to western powers starting
with the Opium War, even though China was supported to be on the
winning side of the war. But the fact remains that there is more
Mongolians actually live in China (in regions called inner Mongolia)
than in Mongolia, and China has given substantial economic and social
support to Mongolia over the last 30 years, especially after its
economy took up. Mongolia is certainly free to seek help from other
countries like India and US, but it can't escape its geological situation
and time. But Dalai Lamas was a puppet of China during the Qing,
as both Tibet and Mongolia were part of China.

So, because this incarnation of the Dalai Lama wishes not to be a "puppet of China" under the Communists, he should be shunned?

Your comment suggests that, like the Chinese people of the Qing Dynasty, Mongolians (and Tibetans living in those places where their ancestors have traditionally lived) must acquiesce in the face of pressure from an overweening regime led by the Communist Party of China, irrespective of what Mongolians and Tibetans want.

How does that differ from what China was subjected to by the European imperialist powers of the 19th Century (and the Japanese imperialism of the 20th)?

Nice, challenging little Tuesday entry.

Being an Ohioan by birth, I naturally threw in TOLEDO at 42A. When, however, it started looking like a source of trouble, I tossed it into the lake, and a few new crosses quickly showed me that the correct answer was LORAIN.

With a clue like "Soldiers' digs," who could blame me for immediately putting in FOXHOLES, but like TOLEDO, it just wouldn't work, and TRENCHES ended the problem.

CoZ,

UCAL is an abbreviation for the University of California that appears often in crosswords, and almost never anywhere else. "Cal," or "UC Berkeley," yes. "UCal," not so much.

Clemens should get into the Hall because of what he did with the Red Sox *before* he used steroids. It's only with Toronto and the Yankees that he used them. (Asterisks for the Yankees championships of 1999 and 2000!)
His numbers at that point weren't HOF worthy though, were they?

"Only"? That encompasses eight seasons. Not to mention three more with Houston. His telling Congress that "I never used steroids. Never performance-enhancing steroids." requires quite a suspension of disbelief. Which apparently is a requirement of hero worship.
What an excellent example of leadership; living and walking his talk. Wonderful, Mr. Adams. And lucky constituents.

Huh, so you equate teaching historical facts (Columbus's role in the age of exploration) with teaching Communist Party propaganda? Well, don't worry - I'm sure you can find a school in the US that teaches commie propaganda as truth.
This is what Commies do - They lie and then they brainwash and push propaganda to cover up the lies. Why is anyone surprised?

Watch Chairman Trump (with President Elect Putin) outdo the Chinese.

Agree with Trump/Putin or be jailed - 'Lock her up' will become 'Lock us up'.

China has its own value system, just like the west countries have their, plus
plenty of hypocrisy. The west's feeling of superiority over that of Chinese
rooted largely in the age old racism over the last few centuries. The Chinese
had enough experience how they had fared under the western dominance,
and they seem to have more confidence in themselves nowadays. Good for
them!
and where do all these fake postings of supposed American sources originate? They do provide great comedic relief on this side of the world!

What a nonsensical history posited by RL  . What froze our politics was unprecedented Republican obstruction that led to government shutdowns, mindless routine filibusters  and threats to default on payments for services already rendered basically that led to a credit downgrade from S&P . Even as approval ratings for Congress sank to 9% thanks to this grinding exhibition, the Republicans have been rewarded by voters , at least the ones that support establishment Republicans. The right wing populism of the Tea Party has moved into the person of Donald Trump who will take office as a compromised man , low approval ratings, supported by a foreign power, and voted against by a numerical majority of Americans. A ludicrous figure who stoked the worst passions, temperamentally unfit and a needy narcissist. It's time for those opposed to this mess  to learn something from Republicans now. THAT is what this article is about

Nice evening to stay home and do the puzzle in bed. Eight inches of new snow and twenty-two degrees. We get an arctic freeze next-woohoo. Single digit lows all week, then more snow. I might as well gone ahead and moved to Canada.

Nice Tuesday puzzle with a subtle theme. Thanks for fine time.
One effective cost-savings: Require the Republicans who have shut down the government twice (and led by Mr. Gingrich once), to pay back the money the nation lost.

C-3p0:

I know Western Europe very well, and I know them to be among the most unchained of the potted liberati; and that's fine, because a sensible American may love visiting, but ...

Our whole problem is that the only people who have regarded themselves as political players for some time are either on the far-left or the far-right. We seem to have kicked everyone else out of Congress. That's WHY Trump is necessary. We need someone with a sense of humor to deal with these yahoos.

Trump doesn't have sense of humor? Of course he does. He charged the whole election to Bill Clinton's AMEX card. You want the number?

I hope President Obama institutes all 7 Robert Reich's recommendations 7 recommendations. #4. Protect the civil service from the Trump transition. Instruct all Cabinet departments and agencies not to respond to any Trump transition team inquiry that might intimidate any individual members of the civil service. #5. Issue an executive order protecting the independence of all government fact-finding agencies, i.e. Bureau of Labor Statistics, Bureau of Economic Analysis, Bureau of Justice Statistics, National Center for Education Statistics, National Center for Health Statistics, National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics, U.S. Census Bureau and U.S. Energy Information Administration... See http://www.newsweek.com/robert-reich-seven-things-obama-should-do-he-lea...

I hope President Obama institutes Robert Reich's seven recommendations, which include #4: Instruct all Cabinet departments and agencies not to respond to any Trump transition team inquiry that might intimidate any individual members of the civil service. #5. Issue an executive order protecting the independence of all government fact-finding agencies, i.e. Bureau of Labor Statistics, Bureau of Economic Analysis, Bureau of Justice Statistics, National Center for Education Statistics, National Center for Health Statistics, National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics, U.S. Census Bureau and U.S. Energy Information Administration....http://www.newsweek.com/robert-reich-seven-things-obama-should-do-he-lea...

In my field, chemistry, there are only enough faculty positions for 10 percent of PhD graduates to become faculty (eventually). The remaining 90 percent must make their way in industry, an area where supervisor's lack of expertise is magnitudes higher. The potential for new hires to skate by with impressive sounding credentials, or for those seeking promotion or junkets based on easy-to-attend conferences is that much easier. This was under-reported in the article and magnified by so many professors saying "not at my school" with indignant tones.

Academic ivory towers benefit by skimming the creamiest of the crop, but they are also the most well-positioned authorities to become arbiters of which journals and conferences are legitimate. Without their exercise of this responsibility, entire disciplines risk becoming marginalized. The result that science is accused of being nothing more than another lobby, seeking its place at the trough--where there is no truth, just special interests--is not shocking.

It is unfortunate that many of the tenured select say it's not a problem for real institutions or legitimate professors! It is this ostrich-in-the-sand attitude that lets our most respected representatives make the other 90% of doctoral students feel left in the breeze upon graduation with historically poor job prospects.
No mandate when the GOP rammed through new voter restriction laws that gave them control of 70 percent of the electoral college votes. Gerrymandering being the most punitive to the people's will.
